titleStmt.title: Persian MS 572
titleStmt.funder: Iran Heritage Foundation and The John Rylands Research Institute

msContents.summary:
The Pandnāmah (Book of Advice), or Karīmā (O Merciful!), a highly-popular book of ethical exhortations and sage advice that while erroneously attributed to Saʻdī (d. 1292), enjoyed broad circulation since at least 150 years after his death.
Francis Gladwin (1744/5–1812) first translated it into English for use as a textbook to instruct British civil servants of the East India Company in Persian. Renowned Delhi scribe Sayyid Abū’l-Ḥasan Rażavī (fl. late 18th-early 19th c.), known as 'Mīr Kallan', completed this copy in 1800. A leading student of master calligrapher Muḥamamd Ḥafīẓ Khān (d. 1780), this volume features elaborately illuminated opening pages. Apparently expertly repaired by a stationer-copyist who replaced four missing folios, then had it rebound in a hybrid British-Indian style.

msItem.title: Pandnāmah (Book of Wisdom)
Pand'nāmah
Karīmā
پند نامه
پندنامه
کریما
msItem.editor: Sayyid Abū-l-Ḥasan Rażavī سید ابو الحسن رضوی , known as 'Mīr Kallan' میر کَلَّن
msItem.incipit: برگ ۱پ (folio 1b): کریما ببخشای بر حال ما * که هستیم اسیر کمند هوا
msItem.explicit: برگ ۱٧پ (folio 17b): منه دل برین دهر ناپایدار * ز سعدی همین یک سخن گوشدار
msItem.colophon: برگه‌های ۱۷پ-۱۸ر (folio 17b–18a): برگهای ۱۷پ-۱۸ر: بتاریخ چهارم شهر ربیع الثانی سنه ۱۲۱۵ یکهزار و دوصد و پانزده هجرة النبی صلی الله علیه وآله و اصحاب المرصلین االکاتب سید ابو الحسن رضوی عرف میر کَلَّن [برگ ۱۸ر] غفر الله تعالی ذنوبه و ستر عیوبه مطابق سنه۴۲ چهل و دویم جلوس ممنت مانوس ابو المظفر محمد شاه عالم پادشاه غازی خلد لله ملکهه سلطانه.

Completed by Sayyid Abū al-Ḥasan Raz̤avī, known as 'Mīr Kallan', probably in Delhi, India on 4 Rabi' II 1215 AH (25 August 1800 CE), equal to the 42nd regnal year of Shāh ʻĀlam II (1728-1806), Emperor of Hindustan (1760–1806).
msItem.note: The final two lines differ from the 1788 edition of Francis Gladwin (1744/5–1812) as does the final word in Arthur Wollaston's (1842–1922) 1908 version, as noted by G. M. Wickens (1918–2006) in the introduction of his translation.

support.p: The textblock contains two types of Indian laid handmade paper; while the majority of the text is written on a medium-weight laid handmade paper, a restorer replaced conjugate folios 3–7 and 12–16 with a comparatively thin, externally sized, and highly polished handmade paper. All pages except for the initial opening feature light brown stencilling in a two-column format.
Flyleaves of mould-made paper watermarked with a lion clutching a shield emblazoned with the St George's Cross, the English flag dated 1863.

foliation.p: Foliation marked at top-centre of the a sides in Hindu-Arabic numerals.

supportDesc.collation:
1IV(8)1V(18). Two sections: a quaternion and quinternion.
Catchwords inscribed at the lower left corners of the b sidesk throughout.

condition.p: Handle with caution: extensive repairs to the gutters and lower margins of the text after apparent water damage. The first and last folios are heavily tipped to the flyleaves in the gutter and so do not open flat. Green verdigris marginal rulings on folios 5, 6, 8–11, and 13 are breaking half way down the inner margin.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 2 columns, with 7 lines per page. Ruled with a miṣṭarah.

handNote.desc: The majority of the text is written in nasta‘liq script in black ink, in a comparatively heavier hand transcribed by Sayyid Abū al-Ḥasan Raz̤avī, known as known as 'Mīr Kallan' with basmallah in blue, and rubricated chapter headings.
Replaced folios 3–7 and 12–16 are written in a more refined nasta‘liq hand in black ink, with rubricated chapter headings.

decoNote.p: A fully illuminated double-page opening on folios 1b to 2a was executed in the early nineteenth century but recalls earlier sixteenth-century Persianate styles. Due to prior damage in the gutter, subsequent repairs, and partial over-painting and re-drawing, the illumination is now in fair condition. The headpiece above the title on folio 1b bears polychrome floral scrollwork, outlined and surmounted by small vertical radiant lines in blue and abutted by a strapwork chain in gold and blue outlined in bright green and an oxidised dark red lead. The initial chapter headings are set between pairs of gold floral scrollwork on a blue ground accentuated by dark red dots, and together with the couplets (the basmalla excepted) are all set within outlined cloud-band reserves set against a gold ground. The gilding is accentuated by tiny interstitial punched dots and is set within a surrounding border of lobed blue half-medallions with palmette scrolls over a gold ground. The remaining folios feature marginal ruling framing the text executed in gold ink outlined in thin black, as well as green, red, and blue.

item.p: Nām-i Karīmā, Aṣghar ‘Alī (Entitled Karīmā [belonging to] Aṣghar ‘Alī).

list.item: Left paste-down, Bibliotheca Lindesiana with shelfmark F/9, and Hamilton MSS No. 489.

decoNote.p: Rebound in straight-grained green goatskin (Type III binding per Déroche, without flap), further embellished with coated medium-green paper onlay strips adhered to form three consecutive alternating narrow and wide decorative rectangular margins, then tooled directly on the book using insular dots on the thinner strips, and a foliate design on the wider one, further outlined and ruled in yellow. While the skin and the pastedowns appear to be of British manufacture, the surface decoration suggests that it was likely bound and decorated in India, hence it is a “British-Indian” hybrid style of binding.
British-made Spanish waved dark blue shell patterned marbled pastedowns line the interior.

bindingDesc.condition: Handle with care: the textblock has partly detached from the binding.

sealDesc.decoNote:
Folio 18a: intaglio-carved seal in with two stacked lines in nasta‘liq script impressed in black ink.
A small square seal of former owner: Muḥammad Valī Khān محمد ولی خان
13 15

history.origin: Probably completed by the scribe Sayyid Abū’l-Ḥasan Rażavī, known as 'Mīr Kallan' in Dehli, India4 Rabi' II 1215 AH (25 August 1800 CE, see colophon on folios 17b–18a).

provenance.p: Formerly owned by Muḥammad Valī Khān (seal impression, folio 18a), and also one Aṣghar ‘Alī (mentioned on folio 1a).

history.provenance: Subsequently acquired by Colonel George William Hamilton (1807-1868) who served in India from 1823 to 1867, latterly as Commissioner in Delhi. He acquired over a thousand Indian and Persian manuscripts of which 352 were selected after his death for the British Museum that are now held in the British Library.
The remainder were purchased in 1868 by Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford (1812–1880).
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847–1913).

acquisition.p: Bequeathed by Enriqueta Rylands in 1908 to the John Rylands Library.

source.p: Bibliographical description based on an index created by Reza Navabpour circa 1993, derived from a manuscript catalogue by Michael Kerney, circa 1890s and his Bibliotheca Lindesiana, Hand-list of Oriental Manuscripts: Arabic, Persian, Turkish, 1898.
Manuscript description by Jake Benson in 2021 with reference to the manuscript.

availability.p: The manuscript is available for consultation by any accredited reader, see Becoming a Reader for details. Please contact uml.special-collections@manchester.ac.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript.

M. H. Razvi and M. H. Qaisar, Catalogue of Manuscripts in the Maulana Azad Library, Vol. V, pt. i: Poetry. (Aligarh: Aligarh Muslim University, 1981), no. 67, pp. 49–50.
